results:
I found comprehensive search results about Polish chivalric tradition, romanticism, idealism, and the fight with windmills in Don Quixote. Here's what the search revealed:

## Polish Chivalric Tradition and Idealism in Literature

In Polish literature, idealism was most often associated with matters of the homeland, with the struggle to regain lost independence.(no content)Polish idealism was most often associated with matters of the homeland and nation.

## Don Quixote as a Symbol of Idealism

Don Quixote can be called an idealist of all time. Don Quixote is an example of an idealist who wants to heal the world and destroy evil.(no content)His life attitude is treated as a symbol of noble idealism that does not take reality into account.(no content)The story tells of a poor nobleman who read medieval chivalric romances and under their influence decided to become a knight-errant. In the company of his trusted squire Sancho Panza, he sets out into the world to help the poor and oppressed, fight dragons and rescue princesses from oppression.

## The Famous Windmill Scene

Don Quixote undertakes a fight with windmills. In his conviction, they are dangerous giants that serve a sorcerer.(no content)One of the most famous scenes of the novel is the episode in which Don Quixote sees three windmills and takes them for terrifying giants with whom he must fight. Hence came the saying "fight with windmills".(no content)It's worth adding that thanks to this novel, the phraseological expression "fighting windmills" was created, which can be explained as fighting something unreal, imaginary. It is a hopeless fight, ultimately having no chance of success.

## Connection to Polish Romanticism

The idealists were the romantics, spreading the idea of faith and feelings against the dried up and limited knowledge of realists. Remember the romantic slogan: "measure your strength by your intentions, not your intentions by your strength." Mickiewicz invented it and rightly shows the way of thinking of idealists: if you want to, you can do it, strength is not important.

## Don Quixote in Polish Literary Context

Don Quixote on Polish roads, that is, dreamers and idealists in Polish literature.(no content)Don Quixote of La Mancha is a literary symbol of idealism.

The search results show how Don Quixote's character has become deeply embedded in Polish literary discourse as a symbol of romantic idealism, with his famous windmill fight representing the noble but often futile struggle against overwhelming odds - a theme that resonated particularly strongly with Polish literature given the country's historical struggles for independence.
